titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Presbyterian Hospital Photograph Collection, 1940-1982 AIS.2007.02
titlestmt.author: Karen Dettloff.

physdesc.extent: (128 Gelatin Silver Prints, 85 35mm Slides, 52 4x5 BW Safety Negatives)

did.abstract: The Presbyterian Hospital Photograph Collection is comprised mostly of images of staff members from the 1940's that were taken by Florence Parry. Additional images in the collection, which date between the 1940's and 1982, document the University of Pittsburgh campus, hospital exam rooms, surgeries and other staff functions.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Karen Dettloff in July 2012.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: UPMC Presbyterian had its beginnings in 1893 when it was founded by Louise Lyle, the wife of a Presbyterian minister.Two years later, in 1895, it was incorporated as the Presbyterian Hospital of Pittsburgh.

In the late 1920s, the University of Pittsburgh was thinking about creating a medical center of its own and asked the Presbyterian Hospital to move away from its North Side location and join them. In return, the University promised them a tract of land for construction of a new hospital. By 1930, ground was broken on the new site. The new hospital officially opened on June 3, 1938.
The Presbyterian Hospital of Pittsburgh and the University of Pittsburgh created a new affiliation agreement that established a three-tiered mission focusing on patient care, research, and education.
By 1950, the hospital changed its name from Presbyterian Hospital of Pittsburgh to Presbyterian University Hospital to reflect its close relationship with the University of Pittsburgh.

The hospital has grown significantly since its founding earning a leading reputation in the areas of critical care medicine, neurology and neurological surgery, oncology, cardiology and cardiothoracic surgery, and organ transplantation. It has also played host to such medical pioneers as Dr. Jonas Salk (polio vaccine), Dr. Peter Safar (emergency medicine and CPR pioneer) and Dr. Thomas Starzl (transplantation pioneer).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection, which dates between the 1940's and 1982, consists of one photograph album housing 128 pictures of hospital staff taken by Florence Perry in the 1940's (the names of the staff are all identified); 52 4x5 negatives of medical professors and physicians at the University of Pittsburgh Medical School and Presbyterian Hospital faculty; and 85 35mm photographic slides of examinations, doctors, University of Pittsburgh medical students, as well as the surrounding Oakland area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The 128 photographic images of Presbyterian Hospital staff taken in the 1940's by Florence Parry include the Dean, Chairmen of various departments (surgery, urology, ob-gyn, orthopedics, internal medicine, proctologist, neurosurgery, plastic surgery, dermatology etc.), and staff. Images are listed in the order that they appear in the album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Early photographs of Presbyterian Hospital including patient rooms, labs, and operating rooms. Also included are views of the Oakland campus, and medical school faculty.
